bookCover.coverDescription: Testing this - what would we add to a cover page?

params.text:
Welcome to the ENGL 100 Library Skills Tutorial!

This tutorial is designed to support you in learning and applying the skills to use CapU Library for research. 

What you will learn

Completing this tutorial will help you to: 

  • explore and narrow a research topic 
  • identify which types of sources are best suited for your research needs
  • identify academic articles and academic books
  • brainstorm keywords to search for sources on your topic 
  • develop your skills in searching the library's Discovery search 

While you may also have a class with a librarian for your English 100 class, the librarian will not be repeating the content of this tutorial. 

What is included in this tutorial

This tutorial consists of text, short videos and practice activities and will take approximately 60-80 minutes to complete. There are 6 pages: 

  1. Exploring a topic
  2. Exploring sources
  3. Identifying academic sources
  4. Creating your search terms
  5. Searching the Library
  6. Summary & Survey

To get credit for completing this tutorial, please ensure you submit the attendance survey linked to on the Summary & Survey page. Check with your instructor to see if there are any other requirements to complete this tutorial, such as a quiz in your course's eLearn page.

How to complete this tutorial

Not sure how to navigate through this tutorial? Watch the short video below to learn how to navigate through and interact with this tutorial.

params.text:
Acknowledgements

We thank everyone who generously shared their work and ideas with us in the creation of this tutorial. We would like to acknowledge that this tutorial uses text, activities and other elements adapted or inspired by: 

  • UBC Okanagan Library's Foundational Library Skills Canvas Course created by Sajni Lacey 
  • Matha Attridge Bufton, David C. Jackson and Marta Samokishyn's Imagine | Question | Search | Synthesize: Critical Foundations for Undergraduate Research course

  • Martha Attridge Bufton and Marta Samokishyn's Critical foundations in undergraduate research: A reading guide

  • Langara College Library's GEOG 1100 Research Workshop, created by Allison Sullivan
  • UCLA Library's Developing Research Questions and Creating Keywords tutorial, created by Renee Romero, Shannon Roux, Taylor Harper, Kian Ravaei, and Doug Worsham

This tutorial is shared with a CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license.

Choosing a Topic

This page will help you explore and refine your topic, and includes some advice on what makes a good research topic.

You’ve received your research assignment, and you need to choose your topic. Or, maybe you have a topic, but you haven’t yet decided on your research question or thesis.

A good research topic is:

  1. Interesting to you
  2. Related to other published research
  3. Specific enough for your assignment

1. Interesting to you

Whether you get to choose your own topic, or choose from a list your professor provides, a topic you are interested in will make the work of researching much easier for you. You do not need to commit to your first idea, and it’s okay to start with a general topic idea. 

You can use brainstorming and mind mapping techniques to generate ideas for your research project.

If you are still deciding on a topic, try the activity below by scrolling through the slides, watching the video and following the prompts to create a mind map for your topic.
Activity: Mapping your Research Ideas

Credits: 
Illustration by Storyset
Johnson, Matthew. "Developing Research Questions and Creating Keywords Workshop." UCLA Library, 2023, https://uclalibrary.github.io/research-tips/workshops/developing-research-questions-and-creating-keywords/

Mind maps are diagrams that can help you visually explore a topic. 

The video by UCLA Library on the next slide will guide you through creating a mind map on your topic on a piece of paper.

If you don't have pen and paper handy, you can create an online mind-map by using the University of Arizona's mind mapping tool.

params.alt: A tweet by Kate Stockings sharing a mind map with climate change in the centre

params.text:
Grab a blank piece of paper and a pen or pencil! Press play when you are ready to start. 

No paper available? Try creating a mind-map for your topic a try by using the University of Arizona's mind-mapping tool.
Draw a circle in the center of your paper and write your topic in the middle. Choose something you are passionate about!
Around the middle circle, write down as many questions about your topic as you can brainstorm.
Narrow down your topic by writing down more specific questions around your existing questions.

params.text:
Some questions you can consider as you create your mind map are: 

  • What interests you about the topic?
  • What do you already know about this topic?
  • What other topics does it make you think of?
  • Are there people, places, or a historical time related to your idea?
Illustrations by Storyset
Reflection

Look at the outer edges of your mind map.

Can you think of 1-3 more specific questions that you are curious about exploring further? 

Did creating a mind map help you explore different aspects of your topic?
Illustration by Storyset

params.text:
2. Related to other published research

A great way to explore a new topic area is to see what others are saying and writing about. 

Exploring your topic is part of research. You can start exploring your topic before you’re 100% certain, and this exploration will help you choose and refine your topic.

The video below shares Jennie's story on choosing a research topic.

params.text:
Search suggestions for exploring your topic

Encyclopedias and other reference sources are a great place to start exploring your topic. 

Scroll through the presentation below to learn how you can use Wikipedia and Credo Reference to start exploring a topic.

metadata.title: Search suggestions for exploring your topic

params.text:
Exploring a Topic:
Using Credo & Wikipedia
Illustration by Storyset

You can start exploring your topic online, by searching in Google, YouTube, or Wikipedia.

The video on the next slide explains how you can use Wikipedia as a starting point to get familiar with a topic, as well as some of Wikipedia's limitations.
Searching online
Wikipedia icons created by surang - Flaticon

summary:
Wikipedia can be a great source to use to help identify terminology and background information related to your topic

You can see the credentials of Wikipedia editors 

Wikipedia articles provide new interpretation and analysis to topics 

Wikipedia covers all important topics from around the world equally

params.text:
3. Specific enough for your assignment

Your assignment instructions will likely include a word count or a page count requirement, and you might be instructed to have a particular amount of sources. For example, your assignment might ask for 2,000 words of writing and five academic sources. 

A specific enough topic will be one that isn’t so broad you would need to write an entire book to explain the main points, and also not so narrow that you are unable to find the sources required by your assignment instructions.

In the video above, we heard Jennie’s story on choosing a research topic. This story is a great example of finding a research topic that is specific enough for your assignment. 

If you need to narrow down a topic, try the activity below to brainstorm more and less specific topics.

Identifying More and
Less Specific Topics
Illustration by Storyset

Activity: More and less specific topics

Draw or save a copy of these three concentric circles. You can use paper and pen, or draw using your device for this activity. 

We'll use these concentric circles to brainstorm more and less specific versions of your research topic.

params.alt: A bullseye icon with 3 concentric circles

params.text: Bullseye icons created by Royyan Wijaya - Flaticon

We'll label each circle in a more or less specific version of a topic.

The outer most circle will have the least specific version of a topic, and the centre circle will have the most specific version of a topic. 

Go to the next slide for an example.

params.alt: A bullseye icon with 3 concentric circles
A bullseye icon with 3 arrows pointing at the outer ring, the middle ring and the innermost circle

params.text: More Specific: Flooding due to climate change
Most specific: The impact of flooding due to climate change on farming in India
Least Specific: Climate Change

params.scoreExplanation: Correct answers give +1 point. Incorrect answers give -1 point. The lowest possible score is 0.

params.text: Mental health
Mental health of university students
Impact of grading policies on university student's mental health

params.a11yCheck: Check the answers. The responses will be marked as correct, incorrect, or unanswered.

params.text: Try for yourself: Drag-and-drop the three topic ideas into place on the graphic from least to most specific.

Try this activity more than once for your research topic idea!

Try placing your topic idea in different circles and brainstorming both specific and more general topic ideas.

There are no wrong answers in this activity. The goal is to brainstorm many different ideas for your topic

params.text:
Choosing your research topic

At the end of this tutorial you might still not be 100% sure about your research topic - that’s okay! If you’ve done the activities on this page then you are further along in the research process.

Choosing your topic is part of the research process. Give yourself time to explore your topic before you decide, but also keep in mind your assignment due date. Check out the CapU Library’s Assignment Planning guide for advice about keeping on track so you can finish your research assignment on time.

Information can be found everywhere

Imagine what you could learn by: 

  • Observing wildlife at a local river
  • Watching people move through and use a popular park
  • Interviewing an elderly family member about their lived experiences

There's also a growing diversity to the kind of recorded information you can find today, from podcasts, videos, articles, social media posts, websites and more.

Different kinds of sources are helpful in different kinds of ways, and you may be required to use specific kinds of sources for class assignments.

Are academic articles the best sources?

You may be required to include academic sources for class assignments. These are sometimes referred to as scholarly sources or peer-reviewed sources. You will learn more about these kinds of sources on the next page. 

Academic sources are not always the best source of information. Here are some examples of when academic articles are not the best source: 

  • You need a general overview of the topic
  • You need a source that discusses current public opinion of the brand new mayor of Vancouver
  • You need company data for a local company

Academic articles don't typically contain these kinds of information. 

Understanding what kind of information can be found in different sources can help you search strategically and save you time. Take a look at the slide presentation below to learn about the best uses for a few different kinds of sources.

metadata.title: Should I rely on academic sources only?

params.text:
Books and Ebooks

Good for:

  • Background information and overviews of a topic
  • Chapters with specific focus
  • In-depth information about a topic

Not so good for:

  • Up-to-date information
Icon created by Freepik

Are they academic?

Books found at CapU Library are often academic, but not always. You will need to investigate further to determine if a book is academic; check out the author, publisher, and whether they cite their sources.

Newspapers and Magazines

Good for:

  • Current events
  • Interviews and eyewitness accounts
  • Insights into public opinion

Not so good for:

  • Academic research
Icon created by Freepik

Are they academic?

No. These kinds of articles are written by journalists who are professional writers, but who may not have subject expertise.

Government Websites and Reports

Good for:

  • Laws, policies and regulations
  • Data and statistics
  • Reports on a variety of relevant issues

Not so good for:

  • Lived experiences
Icon created by Freepik

Are they academic? 

It depends! Some government agencies publish research reports that could count as academic. Depending upon your assignment's instructions, some documents and agency websites will be a better fit than others.

Wikipedia Pages

Good for:

  • Broad summaries
  • Definitions and identifying helpful search words and terminology
  • Citations to more information
  • Up to date information

Not so good for:

  • Analysis or interpretation of information
Icon created by Freepik

Are they academic?

No. Wikipedia is best used as a background source to get a sense of an idea, concept or event you want to research. But it's a starting point, not where your research should end.

Academic Journal Articles

Good for: 

  • Research and analysis critically reviewed by experts
  • Specialized information and discussion of theories, evidence, trends

Not so good for:

  • Background information or a broad overview
  • Information on current events
Icon created by Freepik

Are they academic?

Yes! You will learn more about what makes a source academic on the next page.

metadata.title: Practice Activity: Identifying Voices, Identifying Sources
metadata.extraTitle: Practice Activity: Identifying Voices, Identifying Sources

params.text:
Summary

This section discussed different types of sources available from the CapU Library, and some from the Internet: we covered books, academic articles, magazines, government and popular websites like Wikipedia.

Which type of sources you will need depends on your research question, and also your assignment instructions.

In the next section we will look more deeply at academic sources.

What are academic sources?

Academic sources (also called scholarly sources) are written by experts in a particular field of study and are created to share original research or analyze previous research and advance knowledge in their subject area. Academic authors often have advanced degrees that require 10+ years of study, such as PhDs. 

Academic sources tend to be on very narrow, specific topics and include detailed analysis and discussion of theories, research and issues relevant to a particular subject area.

Authors write these articles primarily for fellow experts and students studying the same subject. 

The most common academic formats are:  

  • academic journal articles

  • academic books

  • conference papers

  • dissertations and theses

What is peer-review? 

Most academic articles are peer-reviewed before they are published. This means that other academic experts carefully review the article and provide the authors detailed feedback before it can be published.

Interested in learning more about what peer-review means? Watch the following optional 3 minute video, created by NC State University Libraries.

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
How to identify academic sources

To spot an academic source, start by looking for the following characteristics: 

  • Author: is it written by and for academics or researchers (professors, engineers, historians, doctors, etc.)? 

  • References: does it include extensive evidence of research in the form of references, works cited lists or footnotes? 

  • Publisher: is it published by an academic publisher? Check to see if the publisher is affiliated with a university. You can try searching for the publisher online to learn more information.

As you become familiar with academic sources, you will notice other characteristics.

metadata.title: How can i identify academic sources

params.text:
Becoming familiar with academic sources 

Take a look at the following academic articles. 

  • Cihuātocameh (Spiderwomen) Weaving Twenty Years of Transformative Justice Work in Higher Education
  • Decolonization is not a metaphor

Reflect on the similarities you notice. For example: 

  • Are the articles long or short?
  • Skim the title and abstract - is the language easy to understand?
  • How many authors are listed? 
  • Do they have similar formatting and layout?

Are academic sources unbiased? 

No. People write and review academic articles, and all people have internalised biases. Academic authors and peer-reviewers are also more likely to be Western, white, men, able-bodied and academic publications overrepresent and centre these voices. 

Academic institutions have a long history of marginalizing BIPOC, disabled, queer and trans people and non-Western knowledge systems. Exclusionary practices are present in academic publishing as well, and the peer-review process can serve to ensure dominant narratives are centred and conformity to academic norms is prioritized. For example, Indigenous academics have spoken out about being asked to cite more white authors by peer-reviewers, and The Cite Black Women Collective calls out the undercitation of Black women, along with the theft and misuse of their ideas and contributions.

As you do research for classes, think critically about all sources you're engaging with and consider: Who are you citing? Whose voices do you want to uplift? What research questions are being asked, and who is being studied and in what ways?

Test your knowledge

Complete the practice activity below to test your knowledge of academic sources.
Illustration by Storyset
Identifying Academic Sources

params.text:
Imagine you found a relevant book on your topic. You check to see if it counts as an academic source and find out the following: 

  • The author is a professor of sociology at the University of British Columbia (UBC)
  • It was published by UBC Press
  • When you look through the book, you see long lists of references

Yes, it is academic.

No, it is not academic.

params.text:
Summary

On this page we covered the defining characteristics of academic books and articles to help you identify academic sources for your research project or assignment. This page and the previous page (which covered different types of sources) will be useful when you are researching at the CapU Library.


The next section will look at creating search terms, and then the final section will cover how to use search terms in the library's website, Discovery, to find the sources you'll need for your research.

Identifying search terms

On this page, you will learn what search terms or keywords are and why they're important when searching library databases. We will also cover a couple strategies to identify and brainstorm keywords for your research topic.

Scroll through the three slides below to learn what keywords are and why you need them to search library databases effectively.
Images created by SlidesCarnival

Library Databases vs Google

Searching library databases is a bit different from searching Google.

Searching library databases is a bit like word matching.

Whatever words you type into the search boxes, the database will try to find in the descriptions or full text of the articles, books, and other items within the database.

That's why you need to search with keywords.
Images created by SlidesCarnival

What are keywords? 

Keywords are words related to the main concepts of your topic.

It's a good idea to brainstorm some alternative keywords too, in case your first search doesn't bring back relevant results.
Images created by SlidesCarnival

Tip: Specific Keywords Work Best

Avoid searching with common words that could appear in any source.

Common words like "effects" and "causes" are often unhelpful for narrowing a search down to sources that are relevant for your topic.

Instead, if these words are part of your research question, brainstorm potential causes or effects and use these as keywords in your search.

params.text:
Identifying keywords in your research question 

If you have a research question in mind, you can use your research question as a starting point for identifying a few helpful keywords. Once you've identified your starting keywords, spend some time brainstorming alternatives in case authors are using different terminology.

Watch the video below to learn more.

metadata.title: Identifying keywords in your research question

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Brainstorming keywords using one relevant source 

You can use Google to help you brainstorm keywords. This is similar to how we discussed using Wikipedia on the Exploring a Topic page.

Watch the video below to learn how to use one relevant source you find through Google to brainstorm more keywords.

metadata.title: Brainstorming keywords using one relevant source

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

metadata.title: Brainstorming keywords using one relevant source
metadata.extraTitle: Brainstorming keywords using one relevant source

params.text:
Keyword choice matters

The keywords you choose will also impact what perspectives you find.

For example, a search for "pipeline protests" will bring back very different results compared to a search for "land defenders." 

To seek out diverse perspectives on an issue, think about what words people on different sides may be using to write about the topic.

Experiment with these keywords and see how they impact your search results - whether in Google or a library database!

Test your knowledge

Complete the practice activity below to practice identifying keywords.
Illustration by Storyset

Planning your Search:

Identifying Keywords

params.question:
Select the 3 most important keywords and phrases in the following research question.  

"How does sleep quality impact stress among university students?"

params.text: Select the keywords

Skimming relevant sources you've already found can be a great way to come up with new keywords and refine your topic. 

Skim the following sentences from an article and write down any keywords you think could be useful if you were researching climate change. 

"Climate change has had unequal and uneven burdens across places whereby the planetary crisis involves a common but differentiated responsibility. The injustices of intensifying climate breakdown have laid bare the fault lines of suffering across sites and scales."
Identifying keywords by skimming a source
Illustration by Storyset

params.text:
Summary

This section covered how to identify keywords in your research question. You will use these keywords to search in Discovery at the CapU Library. The next section will explain how to use your keywords to search Dicovery and find different types of sources.

CapU Library's Discovery search

Once you have a bit of an understanding of your topic and some keywords identified, you can start searching the library for sources!

Discovery is CapU Library's search tool, which you can access on the library's homepage. It searches most of the collection and is a great place to get started with finding resources. 

On this page, you will learn how to:

  • search Discovery using your keywords
  • understand your search results
  • identify academic books and articles in your search results
  • refine your searches using search commands

Conducting searches in Discovery

Scroll through the presentation below and watch the embedded videos to learn the basic mechanics of searching using keywords and phrases, narrowing your search with AND, and expanding your search with OR.
Searching Discovery
Illustration by Storyset

keywords.main: Title page: Searching discovery with keywords and phrases

params.text:
AND tells Discovery to search for all of your keywords and is best used between unrelated keywords.

For example, the search pictured here would look for sources that mention both the word kittens as well as the word stress.
Searching with AND

params.alt: A Discovery search for kittens AND stress

params.text: Searching with Quotation Marks

Some of the key concepts you identified may be phrases made up of 2-3 words. You can search for phrases by putting quotation marks around them. For example, a search for "pet therapy" would search for those two words in that exact order.

Putting it Together

Watch the video on the next slide for a demonstration of how to combine your keywords with AND, use quotation marks, and start to refine your search results by using filters. 

The video will pause a few times to provide you with a bit more information. Read the text that pops up and hit play again when you're ready!

We recommended leaving AND selected between your search bars.

Then, use each search bar to enter keywords related to different aspects of your topic.
Take a look at your keywords. Do you have any phrases? Put quotation marks around them in your list.
Note that there is no need to put quotation marks around single words.

params.intro: Which of the following represents the most appropriate use of quotation marks in a Discovery search?

summary:
"climate change" AND youth

"climate" "change" AND "youth"

"climate change youth"

metadata.title: Searching Discovery using Keywords, Phrases and Filters
metadata.extraTitle: Searching Discovery using Keywords, Phrases and Filters

keywords.main: Video: Searching Discovery with keywords and phrases

params.text:
Expanding and changing your search

If your first search doesn't bring back relevant results, here are a few strategies to try: 

  1. Check your spelling. Library databases don't automatically correct your spelling.
  2. Replace some of your keywords with synonyms or related words. 
  3. Combine synonyms and related search terms together with the search command OR in all capital letters.

Searching with OR

OR tells Discovery and library databases to look for either search term.

For example, a search for kittens OR cats would bring back sources where either the word kittens or the word cats is mentioned.

params.alt: Discovery search for kittens OR cats

params.text:
Video: Searching with OR

Watch the video on the next slide for a demonstration of how to combine synonyms and related words with OR.

params.text:
Your Turn! 

Access Discovery from the library's homepage and try searching using 3-4 of your keywords.

Experiment with some of the search techniques demonstrated on the previous slides.

Look at your results and reflect: Which search strategies and keywords worked best as you were searching?
Illustration by Storyset

params.text:
Identifying what's relevant in your search results

It can feel overwhelming to get a large number of search results.

Thankfully, you do not need to look at all your results to see if your search is bringing back relevant results. 

To check, start by looking at the first page of results. Then: 

  • Look for your keywords in bold in the titles and subjects of your search results
  • Read the abstract, summary or description of an individual item to get a sense of what it's about

Watch the video below for a demonstration.

metadata.title: Identifying relevant results in your Discovery search

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Identifying different kinds of sources in Discovery

Discovery provides you with access to both academic and non-academic sources in a variety of source formats including books, ebooks, academic articles, news articles, video recordings and more. 

Scroll through the presentation below to learn more about how to identify different kinds of sources in your Discovery search results.

metadata.title: Identifying different kinds of sources in Discovery

params.text: Illustration by Storyset
Identifying Different Kinds of Sources in Discovery

keywords.main: Identifying Different kinds of sources in Discovery

params.text:
Source Type Icons in Discovery

Each search result you see will have a small icon next to its title, indicating what kind of source you're looking at. The screenshot below shows an example for a news article.

params.alt: Discovery search result for the news article "Climate change leaves a harmful legacy for future generations" with a news image icon

params.text:
Academic Journals

The Academic Journal icon indicates that you are looking at an article published in a academic or scholarly, peer-reviewed journal. 

Click the image icon below for an example of an academic journal in Discovery search results.

params.alt: Source type icon for an Academic Journal
Discovery search result for "Epistemic injustice in Climate Adaptation" with an arrow pointing at the Academic Journal icon

params.text:
Magazine articles

When you see the Periodical icon, you are usually looking at a non-academic article, such as a magazine article. 

Click the image icon below for an example of an academic journal in Discovery search results.

params.alt: Source type icon for a periodical
Discovery result for the article "How to fix the climate" showing a periodical icon next to the title.

params.text:
Print Books

Physical books CapU Library owns have a call number as well as a location in the library.

The call number is the book's address on the shelf. The location tells you where in the library you will find it. 

This information will appear in your Discovery search results.  Click the image icon below for an example.

params.alt: Discovery result for the book Climate Change by Mike Hulme with arrows pointing at the location and call number

params.text:
Limiting to Academic Articles

Discovery allows you to filter to Peer-Reiewed (Scholarly) Articles, which when checked, will show you only the results that are academic articles. 

You can find this option to the left side of your search results.

params.alt: The Peer-Reviewed (Scholarly) Articles limiter in Discovery
The format limiter in Discovery with magazines checked off

params.text:
Limiting by Format

There are numerous other formats you can limit your results to.

On the left-hand side of your results, you will see a Format section where you can select what kind of sources you want to see.

metadata.extraTitle: Identifying different kinds of sources in Discovery

params.text:
Identifying academic books in Discovery

Not all books you find in Discovery are considered academic. If you want to determine whether a book you've found is academic, the publisher information is a helpful clue. 

Watch the video on the next slide for a demonstration on how to identify publisher information, as well as other clues, in order to idenfity academic books in Discovery.

params.text:
Saving your search results

Discovery includes several features that can be helpful when saving and citing these items. 

For example, you can email yourself a detailed citation and abstract along with the attached full text (HTML or PDF) of an article if you'd like to review it later. 

Watch the video below for a demonstration on how to keep track of your search results by using the email tool.

Test your knowledge

This page covered how to search Discovery and how to understand your search results.

Test your knowledge by completing the practice activity below!
Searching Discovery & Understanding Search Results
Illustration by Storyset
Searching with Quotation Marks

To tell Discovery to exclude certain words

It looks fancier

metadata.title: Photo of exterior of Library building

params.text:
Congratulations

You've made it to the end of the tutorial! By completing this tutorial, you've taken a big step towards being able to complete research assignments at a university level. Hopefully, you now feel more confident: 

  • Exploring a research topic 
  • Identifying which types of sources are best suited for your research needs
  • Identifying academic articles and academic books
  • Brainstorming keywords to search for sources on your topic 
  • Searching the library's Discovery search 

This tutorial covered some of the basics, but it's not your only opportunity to learn how to improve your skills as a researcher. CapU Librarians are available to give advice on:

  • The best places to find articles, books and other resources
  • How to use the available tools, including databases and the library catalogue
  • Where to find information on citing your sources
  • How to plan your research strategy

To connect with a librarian, visit the Ask a Librarian page. 

Completion Survey 

To complete this tutorial and record your attendance, you must complete the following survey!

Please ensure you have gone through the tutorial before submitting this tutorial as it will also ask you for feedback and about what you've learned. 

Completion Survey

noChapterInteractionBoldText: You have not interacted with any pages.
noChapterInteractionText: You have to interact with at least one page before you can see the summary.
yourAnswersAreSubmittedForReview: Your answers are submitted for review!
